entry.title: The Beauty of European Football ‚öΩ
entry.content:
Let‚Äôs talk about Football! Real Football; the sport where you consistently kick the BALL with your FOOT. Now I‚Äôm not an experienced Football pundit, nor am I Messi who knows the ins and out of the game better than anyone on the pitch but I am a strong supporter of the sport. As someone who‚Äôs not constrained to any specific team (go Liverpool and Spurs tho), I find myself watching all the teams in all the leagues: Premier, La Liga, Serie A, Bundasliga, even MLS from time to time.

To me, the beauty of the game isn‚Äôt in the physicality, but the mentality of the sport. Of course, you need to know the intermediate individual skills like shooting in top corners, or dribbling through the defensive lines, or trapping the ball after a drop of 25 feet. But there‚Äôs a secret ingredient: creating space. Now you may present the argument that there are other sports where this ingredient is also crucial like Basketball and American Football. And yes, you are right; it is crucial. But in European Football, a player never has complete control of the ball. In other sports, you can use your hands to hold the ball. In Football, you only have your feet (keeper excluded). This means that space is even more important. In order to have decent control of the ball, you need to ensure there aren‚Äôt too many players near you, hence space.

Navigating through this space is what makes a player top class. You should be navigating whether you have the ball or not. If you‚Äôre a defender, you should close up the possible spaces an opponent striker can squeeze through. If you‚Äôre a midfielder with possession of the ball, you‚Äôre dictating the space of the striker with your through ball or cross. If you‚Äôre a striker with the ball, you‚Äôre looking for the smallest of cracks to squeeze through, you‚Äôre looking for a gap between the goalie‚Äôs legs, you‚Äôre looking for space.

Now as you watch more and more Football, you start to think like the players. You start creating space in your head. There‚Äôs a voice in your head that tells Mohammed Salah to make the run to goal as Trent Alexander Arnold has the ball. To your surprise, Alexander Arnold does shoot the ball to Salah as he makes his run, and 10 seconds later, Liverpool are winning by one goal. That‚Äôs the moment you feel like a king. You feel in touch with the game. You‚Äôre not actually guiding the game but you are in your head. It‚Äôs almost like riding a horse. The horse knows where to go but you‚Äôre the rider. You control the horse even though you don‚Äôt. In this case, you‚Äôre the rider and Football is your beautiful horse.

entry.content:
If you‚Äôve never had Chai before, then stop reading. Go to your local Desi restaurant and ask for Chai right now. For those of you who don‚Äôt know, Chai translates to ‚Äòtea‚Äô in Urdu/Hindi. But I would never call the classic British or American tea, ‚ÄòChai‚Äô. You see, with the translation comes a transformation. Any tea can‚Äôt just be Chai. So what makes Chai, Chai.

For me, it‚Äôs simply the process. To make authentic Chai, you can‚Äôt just boil water and stick a tea bag in there. I mean sometimes that‚Äôs necessary when you just need that extra caffeine boost without spending too much time in preparation, but to really get a quality cup of chai, you have to let yourself be free with the pot.

You see, you‚Äôre not just idle when the water slowly comes to a boil. You stare at the water with such perception that you start to channel your inner thoughts. The water isn‚Äôt water anymore, it‚Äôs a symbol that represents you. You add the tea leaves, the cardamon, the cinnamon, all the spices that you need. They represent the essentials of life. Even with these essentials, the water continues to evaporate. You see yourself struggling and unpleasant. You add the milk, which represents love. There‚Äôs a change in temperature, but soon to your surprise, it starts rising again. The mixture is at a boil once more. It keeps rising and rising until it reaches the top. That‚Äôs where you panic and turn off the heat. You release the pressure. That‚Äôs when the mixture is finally at equilibrium. Your life is at equilibrium. And that‚Äôs when you think to yourself, what the hell is this comparison between life and chai. What was I even thinking about? Oh well, at least I get my cup of Chai! Life‚Äôs good!

entry.title: Rain
entry.content:
It rained today in Berkeley!

I‚Äôm telling you this because I have a special appreciation for rain. To most people, it‚Äôs just water falling from the sky. But for me, It‚Äôs such an exciting natural phenomenon. Every time it rains, there‚Äôs a cool breeze the flows throughout the house. Mornings aren‚Äôt really mornings anymore. The sun isn‚Äôt really out. Instead of feeling the constant urge to pee when you wake up, you feel the coziness of your blanket to an extent you‚Äôve never felt before. You‚Äôre wrapped tight enough for your body to stay nice and warm, but your face is exposed to that cold 62oF air. It‚Äôs actually quite pleasant.

After a quick contemplation of those random, scattered thoughts in your brain, you finally decide to get out of bed. Suddenly, you sense a distinctive aura. The physical change in the atmosphere has created the idea of emotional and mental change in your mind. You‚Äôre filled with hope that this day is going to be different than the past days. It‚Äôs going to be exhilarating, engaging, productive; a day where your actions will portray a flow of spontaneity. You tell yourself that it‚Äôs just an illusion, and you carry on.

After situating yourself in the kitchen, you start boiling water for your morning coffee (instant coffee, of course, this is college, we don‚Äôt have time for a pour-over or a french press). You‚Äôre too tired to make breakfast, so you just warm up one of the Desi sweets your roommate‚Äôs mom left in the fridge for the household. You finally go out to your deck, and that‚Äôs when you really experience the reality of the situation.

Your deck is wet. Telegraph Avenue is wet. The Berkeley hills are wet. There‚Äôs a certain shine on the nearby trees because guess what, they‚Äôre wet. There are people playing spike ball on Memorial Glade and they‚Äôre wet too. Everythings wet. I mean there‚Äôs literally water pouring from the sky, why wouldn‚Äôt things be wet?

Well, that‚Äôs the beauty of rain. It‚Äôs not that it just makes everything wet, but a single act of water pouring from the sky simply changes everything. It changes the way one plays Spikeball because now it‚Äôs easier and softer to dive. It changes the experience of one‚Äôs daily hike through the Berkeley hills because now the water is refreshing and motivates you to push even more. It changes the direction of your stroll through Telegraph Avenue because you don‚Äôt want Pizza anymore, you want Hot Cocoa.

Rain brings change to everything. And change is lovely. When you‚Äôre stuck in a continuous routine, you need change, you want change. You need something to tell you that life is not dull or constant or boring or exhausting, it‚Äôs simply dynamic!

entry.title: Indigo üü£
entry.content:
It‚Äôs a beautiful color, Indigo.

But apart from being a shade of blue, I define Indigo as a feeling. How come you might ask? Well, if Elvis Presley was having a Blue Christmas, and loving him was Red for Taylor Swift, then why can‚Äôt Indigo be my vibe.

Before I even get into the definition of this vibe, you need to know some things about me. For starters, I‚Äôm a very social person. I live for personal interaction and always try to view life from another‚Äôs perspective. I find this to be very refreshing while also being an opportunity to grow as a person. Additionally, I‚Äôm very optimistic. A little too optimistic some might say. I always try to find a silver lining and tend to ignore the negatives in life (This may not always be a good thing tho).

Anyways, now that you know a little bit about my character, I‚Äôll finally try to define Indigo.

Indigo is going to the nearby coffee shop to work. But instead, you end up sharing your life story with the person right next to you simply because you needed their laptop charger.

Indigo is going to class and sitting in that open seat next to a stranger.

Indigo is taking the bus to Trader Joe‚Äôs to find yourself the ingredients for a nice Gouda Grilled cheese. But instead, you end up getting dropped home by a friend of a friend you only met once before and end up sharing your grilled cheese.

Indigo is walking into a party but leaving 5 minutes later to go to Taco Bell with that one person from your CS class who you‚Äôve always wanted to be partnered with for the weekly lab.

Indigo is finally going to that Coldplay concert and singing the lyrics to Yellow with the person right next to you.

Indigo is the feeling of meeting someone you barely know, but in that moment, you feel as if you‚Äôve spent a lifetime with them.

Now that you know what Indigo is, go out there and feel it!

entry.title: Why I Decided to Document My Thoughts

link.title: Why I Decided to Document My Thoughts

entry.content:
You might be wondering, why did I recently develop this urge to write a bunch of stuff and post it for everyone to see. To be honest, I don‚Äôt know myself. What I write over here could literally have no meaning to you. All I do is transcribe my thoughts from my head to this platform. I don‚Äôt even read my drafts sometimes, I just post them. For me, it‚Äôs not so much about the style of writing, it‚Äôs more about the content (even if my sentence structure may not be grammatically correct).

I remember, someone said something to me once about documenting their thoughts. Our brain is a very complicated system and like a lot of complicated systems, it‚Äôs handling a lot of information at the same time. Often times, our brain gets clogged up with random ideas that God knows where we got from. It‚Äôs helpful to empty out our brain once in a while (or at least provide the illusion of emptying it out). Previously, I would just talk to myself sometimes to do this. I could do it for hours. As Michael Scott once said, ‚ÄúSometimes I‚Äôll start a sentence and I don‚Äôt even know where it‚Äôs going. I just hope I find it along the way.‚Äù That pretty much sums it up.

I never know where these short blurbs are going to end up. I just hope in the end, I‚Äôll have something that I can look back to in the future and contrast it with my future thinking and ideologies.

So, if you want a glimpse of what goes on in my head, feel free to keep reading! If not, I totally understand. Sometimes, I even don‚Äôt like what‚Äôs going on in my head LMAO.
